Hi Mark -

As Patrik wrote a few =
messages ago, he has purhased the sword and at the
price, I would think he =
could not had gone wrong with it. Will be quite
interesting to see if the b=
lade has a mei or not! (Trying to get an atari
with my Bungo-to thought!)

=
>Has anyone else out there been denied access to a nakago? I'm curious.

In=
 the past fast-approaching 40 years (now that sound scarey!!) I would
suspe=
ct I've been denied access to a nakago perhaps half-dozen times. If you
hav=
e the opportunity to have the sword in-hand, then at least you can make a
j=
udgement from the blade's quality. If buying it from a photo, well, it is a=

gamble and would certainly limit how much you would offer for it because o=
f
that gamble. I've found that most "owners" will, if you explain it to the=
m
in a knowledgeable and polite manner, will allow the tsuka to be removed.=
 If
buying through the mail, once they learn about the possibility of a
sig=
nature, curiosity usually takes over and off comes the tsuka. (Always
impor=
tant to give clear instructions for doing this such as protecting
habaki, t=
suba, etc., from excessive force!)

When looking at a sword that's presente=
d to you, it is always advisable --=A0
for your own education -- to make a =
judgement about the blade before looking
at the nakago. That alone can save=
 you some money by being dazzled by a "big
mei." All fun stuff!!

Ron
STL

=

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>

Sent: Monday, January 09, 2006 10:04 AM

ct: RE: [nihontostudy] need some advices on a sword...


Hi Patrik,
I am no=
t nearly as knowledgeable in Nihonto as everyone
else on this messege board=
 but I do have an extensive "sales" background. A
couple of things come to =
mind before you buy this piece.
If the Seller is knowledgeable in Nihonto, =
then he would be painfully aware
of how important it is to the Buyer to exa=
mine the nakago. As mentioned
earlier, this should be a simple process. Tak=
ing this one step farther, "if"
the seller is knowledgeable, mabe there is =
something on the nakago that
he/she doesn't want you to see. This would all=
 be related to the asking
price of course. If the seller isn't knowledgeabl=
e, have you explained to
the seller just how simple it would be to remove t=
he tsuka?
Just seems "odd" to me. Has anyone else out there been denied acc=
ess to a
nakago? I'm curious.

Mark Jaillet
